awd_titl_txt: Fast Galerkin Methods for Boundary Integral Reformulations of Time Dependent Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will develop numerical methods for heat transfer and micro flow problems. The focus will be on handling moving geometries that may change the topology over time.  Application areas that immediately benefit from the proposed work are in manufacturing, for instance hot forming processes, solidification and melting processes. Moreover, the numerical solution of micro flows is important in the design of Mems devices, the simulation of microbial swimmers and sedimentation processes. Engineering design is often interactive process, and therefore speed and robustness are essential for the underlying numerical methods.  By engaging a graduate student in research, the proposed activities will also contribute to excellence and growth in the education of the future workforce.

Galerkin boundary integral methods are an effective numerical tool to solve parabolic partial differential equations.  Boundary integral operators are non-local in space and time, which implies that their discrete counterparts are dense matrices. However, a space-time version of the fast multipole method will be used to overcome the high numerical cost associated with dense matrix algebra.  The main goal of this project is to expand this methodology to problems with moving geometries. Here several new techniques will be developed, this includes quadrature methods to handle the unique singularities of parabolic integral operators and new discretization methods of the space-time boundary manifold which will address the difficulties associated with topology changes.  The numerical methods developed will be applied to transient Stokes flow problems and Stefan problems. This project will also investigate shape optimization techniques to solve for the unknown evolution of the solid-liquid interface. Solving free surface problems by minimizing an energy functional fits well within the variational formulation of the Galerkin discretization and promises to be more robust and stable than the more conventional time stepping methods.

por.por_cntn:
Solving time dependent partial differential equations with boundary integral equation methods has generated considerable interest in the recent past. The advantage of the boundary integral approach is that the PDE posed in a three dimensional domain is reduced to an integral equation on the boundary surface. This reduces the dimension and therefore, the size of the problem at hand. In addition, the need to generate volume meshes is eliminated.

Integral equation methods, however, have their own unique challenges, which stem from the non-locality of integral operators and the singularity of the kernel. The recent years already have seen substantial development in the area. The focus of the present project is to develop and analyze computational methods for the situation where the geometry evolves with time. This is still an area in need of further development.

In this context, we focused on three different scenarios.

(1) The case where the motion of the geometry is known a-priori. Applications include computing drag forces in the design of Micro Electro Mechanical Systems (MEMS), and modeling the propulsion of micro swimmers, such as amoeba and spermatozoa.

(2) The case where the evolution of the geometry is a priory unknown, and depends on the current state of the system. This includes Stefan problems which describe the evolution of a liquid-solid interface in melting and solidification problems.

(3) Problems where the evolution of the geometry is hidden from sight, and the goal is to reconstruct the geometry from indirect information. For instance, consider a metal can that contains an ice cube. The task is to reconstruct the melting from the measured temperature and heat flux on the outside of the can. This type of problem falls into the wider class of inverse problems.

As in the case of a fixed geometry, the numerical approaches to solve the boundary integral equation are the Nystrom and Galerkin method. The latter has better stability properties whereas the former has less computational overhead but is reliable only if all surfaces are smooth. While we believe both methods have there merits, we concentrated our efforts of the Galerkin method for their wider applicabilty. Here we developed efficient methods to calculate the coefficients of the linear system. In addition, we developed a fast multipole type method for evaluating the thermal layer potentials in optimal complexity.

To handle the problems with a free or unknown surface we developed a shape optimization approach. Here the unknown surface is initially a guess, which is iteratively improved by minimizing an error functional. At each iteration we have to solve a boundary integral equation that describes the current state of the system. Here the methodology developed for problems with a known geometry can be used to great effect.

The included figures illustrate the actual shape as a wire frame and the reconstruction in solid colors. For clarity, we show a moving curve in two dimensions. The vertical axis corresponds to time.

The grant involved one undergraduate, one Master's and three PhD students. The three students who graduated found meaningful employment in the US where they use the analytical and computational skills gained by working on the project. The MS student is female, after graduation she started a family and works as software engineer of a start up company. The undergraduate and one PhD student work in the financial industry. The second PhD student will defend in summer of 2021 and the third will probably defend in 2023.
